title: RS22044
content: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) provides federal funding to states for education of children with disabilities, requiring states to offer a free, appropriate public education (FAPE) to all such children. Prior to P.L. 105-17 in 1997, states had to ensure participation of children with disabilities in private schools, leading to variations in implementation and court interpretations. Prior to P.L. 105-17 in 1997, differences in interpretation of the IDEA and the "equitable participation" standard among states and courts led to varying levels of services for children with disabilities in private schools. The IDEA Amendments of 1997 rejected the "equitable participation" standard and required provision of special education and related services to children with disabilities in private schools, funded proportionately by federal funds. The IDEA Amendments of 1997 required provision of special education and related services to children with disabilities in private schools, funded proportionately by federal funds. The 2004 reauthorization further clarified the responsibilities of local educational agencies to ensure fair and equitable services for children with disabilities in private schools. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA clarified the responsibilities of local educational agencies regarding children with disabilities in private schools. It addressed issues related to private school placements and the provision of services, emphasizing the importance of fair and equitable treatment for all children with disabilities. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA clarified the responsibilities of local educational agencies regarding children with disabilities in private schools. Children with disabilities enrolled in private schools by their parents are entitled to special education and related services, with the requirement that they be located in the school district served by the LEA. This provision aims to protect LEAs from having to work with private schools in multiple jurisdictions, although it has sparked controversy. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA clarified the responsibilities of local educational agencies regarding children with disabilities in private schools. It includes provisions for funding and services for parentally placed private school children, emphasizing direct services over indirect services. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA clarified responsibilities for private school children with disabilities. It added provisions for calculating proportionate amounts, maintaining records, and supplementing funds. The law allows services on private school premises, including religious schools. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA clarified responsibilities for private school children with disabilities, including provisions for child find, equitable participation, activities, cost, and completion period. The law ensures services on private school premises, including religious schools, and emphasizes accurate counting and serving the intended purpose of funds. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA clarified responsibilities for parentally placed private school children with disabilities, including requirements for LEA consultation, determination of federal funds, consultation process, provision of special education services, and alternate service delivery mechanisms. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA clarified responsibilities for parentally placed private school children with disabilities, including requirements for LEA consultation, determination of federal funds, provision of special education services, and compliance procedures for private school officials to submit complaints to the SEA regarding consultation processes. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA outlines procedures for private school officials to submit complaints to the SEA regarding consultation processes and provision of equitable services by public agencies. Private school officials can escalate complaints to the Secretary of Education if dissatisfied with the SEA's determination. Services provided to private school pupils must be secular, neutral, and nonideological, with funds controlled and administered by a public agency. The cost of private school placement for children with disabilities is not paid by the LEA unless certain findings are made by a hearing officer or court. The new law specifies conditions under which reimbursement cannot be reduced or denied, including situations where the school prevented the parent from providing notice or compliance would likely result in physical harm to the child. Additionally, reimbursement may not be reduced or denied if the parent is illiterate or cannot write in English, at the discretion of a court or hearing officer. The Supreme Court's recent decision in Board of Education of the City School District of the City of New York v. Tom F. ruled that parents of a child with a disability are entitled to private school reimbursement even if the student never received special education services from the school district. This decision does not set a precedent for lower courts, and the issue remains unsettled.
